results.title: Secrets of nature: summertime meadow
results.creator_credit: Associated British-Pathe and British Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Views of typical animal and plant life to be found in an English meadow during summer; ladybirds feeding on aphids; meadow flowers and pollination by bees; snails; grasses and grasshoppers; the looper caterpillar, drinker moth and millipede; swallow-tail butterfly; burnet moths; blue, marbled white, fritillary butterflies; various types of meadow grasses.
results.description: Views of typical animal and plant life to be found in an English meadow during summer; ladybirds feeding on aphids; meadow flowers and pollination by bees; snails; grasses and grasshoppers; the looper caterpillar, drinker moth and millipede; swallow-tail butterfly; burnet moths; blue, marbled white, fritillary butterflies; various types of meadow grasses.

results.creator_credit: Associated British-Pathe and British Instructional Films

results.title: Secrets of nature: gnats
results.creator_credit: Associated British-Pathe and British Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Shows the life cycle of the gnat; laying of eggs in batches of two to three hundred; emergence of the larvae; structure of the larvae showing head, thorax, abdomen in ten sections; head equipped with compound eyes; feelers; bristled jaw and breathjing tube; effect of oil layer on surface of water; change to pupae; emergence of the winged insects; biting action of the female gnat.

results.title: Secrets of nature: daphnia (water fleas)
results.creator_credit: Associated British-Pathe and British Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Microcinematography of the crystalline and long-tailed water fleas. Shows the digestive system, the heart, the eye and the reproductive methods of the common water flea.

results.title: Second report on modernisation
results.brief_description: Recent progress in the modernisation and electrification scheme for British Railways. Illustrates some of the new architectural and engineering techniques employed in building railway stations, flyovers, marshalling yards, freight trains and deluxe Pullman carriages. Electronics and automation are prominent features of the new face worn by British Railways’ tracks, stations and offices, and a glimpse of modern training and living facilities for staff is also included.

results.title: Sebastian the fox: the sleepwalkers
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: Puppet film featuring Sebastian Fox up to his cunning tricks again - disturbing the sleep of two grown-ups. He pulls off the bed-clothes, then frightens them by appearing as a ghost. Finally, Sebastian locks out the couple and takes over the bed. Puppets by Peter Scriven.

results.title: Sebastian the fox: the painter
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: Sebastian the Fox enters an artist’s studio and does some painting himself, while the artist and his model are having tea. He is made to clear up the mess he makes and told to leave, but Sebastian has his revenge. Photography by Giorgio Manianele.

results.title: Sebastian the fox: the animal catcher
results.brief_description: Another adventure for Sebastian the Fox when he is caught by Professor Catchem, licensed animal catcher and pet shop owner. A young boy decides to buy Sebastian when he sees him in the display window, but Sebastian is too clever and outsmarts the boy and the professor. Puppets by Peter Scriven. Music by George Dreyfus.

results.title: Seaway to the heartland
results.creator_credit: Fred Gorman Films and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This is the story of the St. Lawrence Seaway, its construction, its operation and its impact on our economy. It gives a brief historical review of the earlier canals, which were built as long as two hundred years ago. Narrated by Bob Gardiner.
results.description: This is the story of the St. Lawrence Seaway, its construction, its operation and its impact on our economy. It gives a brief historical review of the earlier canals, which were built as long as two hundred years ago. Narrated by Bob Gardiner.
